p: The fact that occluding the external auditory meatus lowers the hearing threshold for BC sound has been known as the occlusion effect since the 19th century ( 7). The occlusion of the external auditory meatus improves hearing thresholds by 10â€“20 dB at frequencies of 250 and 500 Hz ( 7, 9). As 500-Hz tone bursts are usually used for recording VEMP, occlusion of the external ear canal seems to be beneficial for inducing VEMP responses although it depends on the mechanism underlying the occlusion effect.
